did.abstract: Personal papers of the Skinner Family. Includes correspondence reflecting the events and activities which affected the lives of early pioneer families in Central New York.

repository.corpname: State University of New York at Oswego

accessrestrict.p: This collection is open to the public with restrictions, as some items are fragile and are damaged.

bioghist.p: The Skinner family consisted by Timothy Skinner (1761-1843), Ruth Warner Skinner, his wife (1770-1849), and their nine children – Warren, Cynthia, Alanson, Avery, Hiram, Dolphus, Barton, John, and Albert. Growing up in Westmoreland, New Hampshire, the Skinner children, like so many other young men and women in the early nineteenth century, moved west from their parental home to settle across upstate New York and Ohio. At least three of them (Warren, Dolphus, and Barton) became ministers, and one (Albert) became a doctor. Others became teachers, farmers, or businessmen.

Letters in this collection center principally around three of the children – Cynthia, Avery, and Hiram – who settled in Union Square (now Maple View), Oswego County, New York. Letters from Avery’s wife, Charlotte, also form an important part of the collection.

Cynthia Skinner, the second oldest of the siblings, migrated to Brownville, Jefferson Co., New York in 1824. After her marriage to Hiram Walker in February 1829, she settled with him on his farm in Union Square, New York.

Avery Skinner (1796-1876), the fourth child in the family, became one of its best known members. Operating a tavern in Union Square, at the junction of the busy Rome-Oswego and Syracuse-Watertown trade routes, he was well-known not only for his business activities but also for his Universalist religious beliefs and his Democratic politics.

As a young man Avery attended the Chesterfield (New Hampshire?) Academy, teaching in winters to pay his expenses. He migrated to Watertown in 1816 where he remained for six years as a teacher. In 1823 he relocated in Union Square, where he not only names the village but built the first tavern, set up a mail route and became the first postmaster, an office he held until his death. In addition to his other business activities he helped develop plank roads in the 1840s, was a member of the first Board of Trustees of the Rensselaer-Oswego Academy in Mexicoville, and was a promoter and director of the Syracuse Northern Railroad.

Building on his local prestige, Skinner became a prominent Democratic politician in Oswego County, holding various county and state offices from 1826 through the mid-1840s. On the county level he served as county treasurer from 1826 to 1838 and as an appointed judge of the Court of Common Pleas from 1828-1839. On the state level, he was elected a member of the assembly in 1831 and 1832 and later (1838-1844) served as state senator. In 1846 he ran for Congress but was defeated by William Duer.

He married twice. His first wife, Eliza Huntington (1804-1833) died shortly after the birth of her fifth child. In 1934 Skinner married Charlotte P. Stebbins (1802-1888), a long-time friend of the family. He had several children – Lucretia, Timothy, Solomon, Avery, Eliza, James, Charlotte, Albert, Charles and Mary Grace. Some of these died in childhood but others went on to become prominent citizens in their own right. Timothy, for example, became a lawyer in Mexicoville, and Charles became Superintendent of Schools in New York State. Avery Skinner dies in Union Square on November 24, 1876.

Hiram Skinner (1801-1831) was the fifth child of Timothy and Ruth. He moved to Union Square in 1825, where he began business as a storekeeper. He failed in business as a result of extending long-term credit to his customers. He later sustained injuries after a bad fall and became virtually a ward of his wealthier brother, Avery. He married his wife, Noralla, in 1831.

scopecontent.p: Personal letters makes up the bulk of the Skinner family papers. Most of these letters were written by Cynthia Skinner Walker, Hiram Skinner, and Avery Skinner to their parents in Westmoreland, New Hampshire. Some of the correspondence is also between Avery and his second wife, Charlotte Stebbins Skinner, while Avery was in New York State Legislature in Albany. Most of this material dates between 1815, when Avery moved to Watertown from his parental home, and 1844, when he returned to Union Square from his last term in the state legislature. There is also some material relating to two of Avery’s children (Charles and Mary Grace), some genealogical information on the Skinner family, Avery Skinner’s will, and some clippings and photographs.

The collection is particularly valuable for the information it contains on family relationships. Avery, Hiram, and Cynthia’s letters to their parents reflect fond remembrances of the happy home life they enjoyed as children. And correspondence between Avery and Charlotte provides interesting insights into their marital and family life. The collection also illustrates the problems experienced—particularly by Avery and Hiram—in establishing oneself in the world. Finally, the letters contain material on the religious attitudes of the Skinner family (most of whom were Universalists), a few references to Anti-Masonry, and some information on life in Watertown and Union Square.
